Mwanamkasi operates a firewood selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other firewood operators.
 
She requests a loan of KES 45,000 to purchase 6 bunches of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support of the previous loan.

loans.use: to purchase 6 bunches of firewood.

loans.name: Boris Jose

texts.es: Boris es un campesino de 51 años de edad que se dedica a trabajar como aserrador independiente, con más de 10 años de experiencia en la labor, en algunas ocasiones compra lotes de bosque para talar los árboles y luego comercializar la madera, pero en otras ocasiones cuando no tiene capital disponible sólo le pagan la mano de obra, adicionalmente y, para complementar los ingresos él posee un cultivo de café, cuya cosecha recolecta y vende en la plaza de mercado de la región, de esta forma obtiene los recursos suficientes para solventar las necesidades de su hogar. Su empuje, tenacidad y su constante lucha le han permitido seguir adelante, cumpliendo las metas que se propone, por ello solicita el  apoyo del crédito con el que desea comprar un lote de bosque para talarlo y así poder aumentar su producción de madera, lo que se reflejará en el incremento de sus ingresos lo que para él significa poder brindar a su familia un mejor bienestar, aun cuando es consciente de los riesgos que corre realizando esta labor.  Boris sueña con poder plantar árboles para que en un futuro le permita aserrar su propio bosque y así mejorar la entrada de recursos económicos con los que puede ofrecer mejor calidad de vida a sus seres queridos.
texts.en: Boris is a 51 year old farmer who works as an independent woodcutter. He has more than 10 years experience doing this work. At times he buys wood lots to cut down the trees and then sell the lumber. At other times, when he doesn't have capital available he just gets paid for the labor. In addition, and to supplement his income, he grows coffee. He collects the harvest and sells it in the plaza of the regional market. In this way he has enough resources to pay for his household expenses. His drive, tenacity and his constant fight have allowed him to get ahead, meeting the goals he sets for himself. That is why he is asking for the help of the loan. With it, he wants to buy a wood lot to cut it down and sell the lumber he harvests. This will be reflected in an increase of income which for him means more wellbeing for his family, even knowing the risks he faces doing this work. Boris dreams of being able to plant trees so in the future he can cut his own wood and in that way improve his financial resources so he can offer a better quality of life to his loved ones.

loans.use: to buy a wood lot to cut.

loans.name: Annabel

texts.en:
Annabel is 32 and married with three children. She runs a retail business, selling food and snacks in their community. She also has been selling sausage for more than three years. 

In 2007, Annabel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Her previous loan was used in the business and was successfully repaid. Recently, she obtained a loan to buy more sausage, snacks and beverages to resell. She wants to improve the business and to have a stable income for the family. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy more sausage, snacks and beverages to resell.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is married and has been blessed with two children. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children.

For the past two years, she has operated a food stall business, selling household consumables like wheat flour, rice and cooking oil. She cites theft and competition as her major challenges in her business. 

She is requesting KES 20,000 to boost her kiosk. She will use it to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed, 24m lives in Taiz, Yemen. He’s a responsible, hardworking entrepreneur with a wish for personal self-improvement. He has been presented with an opportunity to be able to improve his house. This is of great importance to his family, as they will be able to live in better conditions. For this reason, he is requesting a second loan of 250,000.00 YER from AMB to buy construction supplies to improve his home and complete building the second floor. He is grateful to the Kiva lenders who help with credit and who always think of the poor people and give them opportunities to get ahead in life.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies to improve his home and complete building the second floor.

loans.name: Primitivo

texts.en: Primitivo is married with three children, and he manages his own farm to make a living. He plants corn and harvests coconut and sells it in town. He joined GDMPC and borrowed a loan to purchase fertilizer like manure. He wants to improve his farm by having a weeding maintenance regularly. In the future, he wants to improve the general living situation of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann is 45 years old, married and supports three members of her family. She runs a retail business in Awasi and is served by the KADET Kapsabet office. This has been her income-generating business for the last thirteen years, and she generates an average monthly income of 15,000.KES. She plans to use this loan of 20,000 KES to buy sugar, rice and flour as additional stock for her business. She plans to use the anticipated profits to pay back her loan and also open another shop.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice and flour as additional stock  for her business

loans.name: Procorpio Jr

texts.en:
Procorpio Jr , 47, is married with an only child. He manages his own farm for a living. He has been planting and harvesting rice for more than ten years. 

In 2011, he joined GDMPC and recently borrowed a loan to buy fertilizer and organic fertilizer. He wants to gain an abundant harvest in order to use it for the education of his child. He wants to have a comfortable house and improved living situation for the entire family in the near future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Margarida

texts.en: Margarida is applying for a loan of $1,200 from TRM (Tuba Rai Metin). She is 38 years old. She is running a kiosk in front of her house and she will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store such as paper, colored ink, rulers, scissors, and a copy machine. She is making good money from selling and she wants to apply for a bigger loan in the future. Margarida is living in a town near by the school. Her kiosk is located in a strategic place where many people, including students, come to buy.

loans.use: to buy paper, colored ink, rulers, scissors, and a copy machine.

loans.name: Gold Group

texts.en:
Rose, who is in her early 40s, is married with a boy who is in school. For a period of four years now, Rose has been managing two small businesses, a clothes business and a cooking oil business, selling door to door. She starts working at 8 am and works until 8 pm each working day and is able to make fair returns each month.

This will be her sixth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to buy cooking oils and more clothes to resell. Rose has managed to pay back all her previous loans successfully. She used her business profit to pay school fees and home expenses. Rose, who started her business with a small amount of capital, is working hard to see her business become a great success. She will use this loan to increase on business stocks for both her businesses. Rose dreams that one day she will be able to expand her projects to generate greater returns.

Rose will share this loan with her loan group "Gold” which totals 6 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase on business stocks to resell.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is 30 years old and is married to Paul. They have been blessed with 1 child. She runs a grocery business in Makueni town. She has been in the business for 3 years and it has been profitable. 

She plans to use this loan to buy more grocery stock to sell including tomatoes, onions, and vegetables. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her child. 

This is her second loan and she paid her previous loan successfully. Annah hopes to grow her business, make more income, and be able to support her family.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, onions, and vegetables.

loans.name: Felimon Jr.

texts.en: Felimon Jr. is married with one child. He runs a retail business selling used shoes in the market. Aside from this, he also has been engaged in a transportation service to earn a living. He also uses his motorcycles in selling used shoes. Recently, he borrowed a loan from GDMPC micro credit to repair the existing vehicles used in his business. He hopes to sustain his business to earn a stable income in the future.

loans.use: to repair the existing vehicles used in his business

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita is running a furniture making business in the village of Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur to earn a living. She is separated from her husband and is the only one to provide for the needs of her only child. 

Perlita joined GDMPC in 2007 and recently obtained a loan to buy more raw material for furniture making. Hopefully, in the near future, the business will  improve and she can support her child's education.

loans.use: to buy more raw material for furniture making.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a farmer in Tala town where she does dairy farming and also plants cash crops for selling. She is 40 years old and together with her spouse they have been blessed with 3 children. She has been in the farming business for the last 12 years and she makes a monthly income of KES 30,000.

Elizabeth plans to use this loan to buy farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds. She also plans to buy dairy feeds for her dairy cows. She anticipates  making more income with which she will save and also repay the loan.

Elizabeth hopes to be successful in her farming business, make more income and be able to educate her children to tertiary level.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs and dairy feeds.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 24 years old, and provides for two members of her family. She has been in the hotel (restaurant) business for the last two years, earning a monthly income of 2,800 Kenyan shillings (KES). She operates her business in Kipsebwo, which is served by Kenya Agency for Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) Kapsabet office. She has borrowed 20,000 KES and plans to buy stock such as rice, flour and cooking fat for her hotel. She will use the profits from the hotel business to repay her loan and her dream is to open a boutique.

loans.use: to buy stock such as rice, flour and cooking fat for her hotel

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en: Juanito is 44 years old with two children. He raises corn and vegetables to earn a living. In 2011, Juanito joined GDMPC and his previous loan that was used to buy fertilizer was successfully repaid. He always find ways to augment their living. He plans to expand his farm and borrowed a new loan to purchase fertilizers and additional seedlings.  In the future, Juanito wants to improve the general living of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and additional seedlings

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman and has two children. She owns a house that has no piped water but has electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children.
 
She has operated a tailoring business for the past five years. She makes women's and men's outfits. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a wholesale business making clothes in the future. 

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Mirza

texts.en:
Mr. Mirza is a 34-year-old married man and active borrower of BRAC Pakistan, living in Punjab, Pakistan. His wife is a very hardworking and responsible housewife. 

Since 2000, Mr. Mirza has owned a hardware shop which is the only source of income for his family. He sell variety of hardware like needles, paint, hammers, bulb holders, bulbs, etc. in the shop. He belongs to a middle class family. 

Presently he needs to purchase a ariety of bulb holders and bulbs for the shop. For that reason, he has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan. This will help him to purchase the needful things and to fulfill the demand of customers more efficiently. He desires to provide quality education to his children. He is very much thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase bulbs and bulb holders for the shop.

loans.name: Yasser

texts.en:
Yasser is a 29-year-old married man who lives in Ibb, Yemen.  He is a hardworking man who operates a buffet in which he has offered his customers all types of staple foods, such as hot drinks, fresh juices and sandwiches for 3 years. He knows how to attract customers and offer what they need.  

Now, he would like to stock his business, so he applied for a youth loan of 100,000 YER from AMB to order to buy different types of staple products, such as beans, bread, fruit, sugar and spices to expand his business. With this loan, the business will allow him to support his family and increase his profit. He hopes to improve his living standards.

loans.use: to buy different types of staple products, such as beans, bread, fruit, sugar and spices to expand his business.

loans.name: Aza

texts.en:
Aza is 50-year-old married woman. She lives in a small village of Kobuleti district with her husband, son, daughter-in-law and an infant granddaughter. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have cows and produce cheese products to sell. In addition, they have a plot of land, where they grow nuts and walnut trees. 

Aza decided to start her own business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of $4500 to start selling clothing and linens. She will purchase products in Turkey and will sell among her villagers to generate income. The Start Up loan, will be a great support for their family.

loans.use: to begin selling clothing

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah  is 26 years old, married, and supports three members of her family. Her spouse  helps in fending for the family, too. She is into a milk vending  business in Chepterit and she is served by KADET's Kapsabet office. This has been her income-generating business for the last three years, and she gets an average monthly income of Kshs 15,000. She plans to use the amount borrowed of Ksh.12,000 to purchase  more milk for resale. She will use the anticipated profits to repay her loan. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more milk for resale

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn,   41 years old, is married and has two children. Jocelyn has owned and operated a nipa-mat-making business for more than three years . In 2011, Jocelyn joined GDMPC and her previous loan that was used in purchasing raw materials was successfully repaid. Now she is requesting a new loan to purchase raw materials  and more woven 'nipa' mats to resell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials  and more woven 'nipa' (palm frond) mats to resell

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is married and has two children, one of whom attends school while one is still young. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, she has owned a food stall business; her customers are neighbours and town dwellers.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize, wheat flour and cooking fat. She dreams of expanding to a modern café business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize, wheat flour and cooking fat

loans.name: Faisal

texts.en:
Mr. Faisal is a 39-year-old man who lives with his family in Lahore, Pakistan. Since 2005, Mr. Faisal has been running his own general store near his house, which is a very successful business for his family. He is an active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. He is interested in adding more variety to the store that includes powdered milk, rice, chips, oil, soap, candies and some other items for children as well. 

Due to financial constraints, he finds it difficult. Therefore, he has requested a loan from Kiva's partner, BRAC Pakistan. This will not only help him to grow his business but will also increase his net income and savings. He is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase powdered milk, rice, chips, oil, soap, candies and some other items for children as well.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en: Michelle is running a swine-fattening business as an aid to her husband's income from employment. Her two children are still studying and she needs to prepare for their college education. She joined GDMPC in 2011 and borrowed a loan to purchase feed and other supplies. She plans to save her returns for the future needs of the entire family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and other supplies

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia, 45 years of age, is married to a farmer and they are blessed with three children. She has been in the food vending business for almost thirty years.

She drives a motorcycle with a side car and roams around their village to sell fish, chicken, and pork meat. By doing this, she's earning a net income of PHP 1,000 daily. Her profits are usually spent on school expenses for their son and food expenses for their family. 

Due to lack of capital,  she would like to request a loan from generous lenders amounting to PHP 20,000 to purchase fish, chicken, and pork meat to sell. She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that her business will continue to grow and become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase fish, chicken, and pork meat to sell

loans.name: Maximo

texts.es: Máximo, tiene 39 años de edad, vive en unión libre con su pareja con quien tiene 3 hijos y reside en el municipio de Choloma, Cortes. El trabajo por varios años en una maquila y al quedar sin empleo decidió con su esposa poner una pulpería para obtener ingresos y cubrir los gastos del hogar. En la pulpería vende arroz, frijoles, azúcar, churros, harina, sal, manteca, huevos, pan, condimentos, jabón y otros básicos. Máximo ha solicitado un préstamo por 15,000 Lempiras para  surtir de productos su pulpería como ser azúcar, harina, pan, huevos, manteca, café, arroz y otros productos que necesita. Su plan es hacer crecer el negocio y obtener mayor rentabilidad.
texts.en:
Máximo, 39, lives in a common-law relationship with his partner.  They have three children and live in the town of Choloma, Cortés.

He worked for several years in a factory.  When he lost his job he and his wife decided to start a grocery store to earn income and cover the household expenses.  He sells rice, beans, sugar, chips, flour, salt, shortening, eggs, bread, condiments, soap, and other staples.

Máximo has requested a loan for 15,000 lempiras [HNL] to stock his grocery store with sugar, flour, bread, eggs, shortening, coffee, rice, and other necessary products.  He plans to grow the business and become more profitable.

loans.use: to stock his store

loans.name: Linet

texts.en:
Linet is 37 years old, single, and supports two members of her family.  She runs  a bookshop business in Kamobo that is served by the KADET Kapsabet field office.  

Linet has been in this business for the last three years, earning a monthly income of 10,000 KES.  She has borrowed 30,000 KES and plans to buy books, pens and other stationeries for her bookshop.  She will use the profits to boost her business.  

Her dream is to open a Christian bookshop as well as start a distribution store for school uniforms.

loans.use: to buy books, pens and other stationeries for her bookshop

loans.name: Verginia

texts.en: Verginia has been raising pigs for four years and earns 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) per month. She’s 52 years old now, yet continues to hang on with her piggery livelihood to make an adequate life for her child. She's been a member of Gata Daku Multi-purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) since 2009 and her previous loan that was used in her hog raising business was successfully repaid. She wants to improve the general living of her family and be able to support the future education of her only child.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: jeanne est une femme camerounaise de 47 ans, célibataire et mère d'un enfant. elle possède et gère une comptoir  de vente des produits alimentaires dans un quartier de la ville depuis 12 ans. elle sollicite ce crédit pour acheter un congélateur afin de d'augmenter la capacité de conversation des jus naturels qu'elle fabrique pour accroître ses ventes et profits.les bénéfices générés vont lui permettre d'étendre son activité d'une part et de payer l'éducation de sa fille d'autre part.
texts.en:
Jeanne, age 47, is a Cameroonian woman. She's unmarried and the mother of one child. She owns and runs a stall in one of her city's neighborhoods, where she's been selling food products for twelve years.

She's seeking this loan to buy a freezer in order to increase the production of the natural juices that she makes, and increase her sales and profits.

Her profits will enable her to expand her business on one hand, and to finance her daughter's education on the other.

loans.use: to buy one freezer

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a food-vending business in the Philippines.

She has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Marilyn has been in this business for five years now.  She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila  operates a food stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. She dreams of establishing a hotel in the future. 

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat, and sugar to add her stock. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support of the previous loan which helped her to stock her business well.

loans.use: to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat, and sugar

loans.name: Miguela

texts.en:
Miguela is helping her husband in managing their own farm of corn for a living. In order to gain an abundant harvest, Miguela needs financial funds to improve her farm. 

She had joined GDMPC and recently she requested a loan to purchase organic fertilizer. She hopes to earn more returns and  to save a portion of their income for the future needs of the entire family.

loans.use: to purchase organic fertilizer

loans.name: Nuru Group

texts.fr: La cliente Desange est leader du collectif d’affaire « Nuru », jeune entrepreneur expérimentée, dynamique,  âgée de 32 ans et mère de 3 enfants qui étudient tous. Son conjoint est un modéliste couturier. La cliente est sociétaire d’un atelier de coupe couture. En plus, elle  est vendeuse de matériels de couture. Cependant, elle s’entraide avec son conjoint dans la gestion de leur entreprise familiale de coupe couture. Elle installe son atelier  à un point de vente animé de son quartier, proche du marché public. Elle commença ses affaires avec  l’assistance de son mari. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le  prêt de l’IMF Hekima. Il y a 12 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter les matériels de couture (tissus, mordoré, ciseaux, machines, outils de travail, boutons, mannequins, etc.). Ainsi, elle souhaite scolariser ses enfants, étendre son projet de commerce et construire une jolie maison. Les impayés, les taxes, les charges d’exploitation(loyer) sont de défis pour le développement de son activité. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour l’autonomisation des femmes entrepreneurs non bancables, surtout ; pendant ce moment critique de guerre à l’Est du pays. Il sied de signaler qu'une cliente tient son bébé.
texts.en:
Desange, age 32, is a young, energetic, and experimented entrepreneur. She's the leader of Nuru Group and the mother of three children, who all go to school. Her husband is a tailor. She owns a share in a sewing workshop. Furthermore, she sells sewing supplies.

Her husband and her help each other to run their family sewing business. She sets up her workshop in a busy point of sale in her neighborhood, close to the public market.

She started her business with her husband's assistance. Later on, she was granted a loan from Kiva's partner, Hekima. She's been running her business for twelve years. This new loan will be used to buy sewing supplies (fabrics, golden brown fringe, scissors, work tools and machines, buttons, mannequins, etc).

She wishes to give her children an education, expand her business, and build a nice home. Unpaid bills, taxes, exploitation charges (rent) are challenges for the development of her business.

In the end, she strongly thanks Hekima for its contribution to make women who are excluded by traditional banks self-supporting, especially during this critical time of war in the East of the country. It has to be noted that, in the picture, one woman is holding her baby.

loans.use: to buy sewing supplies (fabrics, golden brown fringe, scissors, work tools and machines, buttons, mannequins, etc)

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is a 36-year-old man, he is married to Mary and a father of three children. He is a milk vendor in Highrise area in Nairobi. He has been in business for 15 years and gets a monthly income of 32,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). 

This will be Henry’s second loan with Kenya Agency for Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET). He plans to use the money to purchase milk. In future, he would like to expand his business to educate his children.

loans.use: to purchase milk

loans.name: Rizel

texts.en:
This is Rizel. She previously accessed an 22,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts and cover maintenance costs of her computer shop. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for a 25,000 PHP loan to buy parts and cover maintenance costs of her computer shop. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Rizel dreams that her business will continue to flourish and hopes to become rich one day. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she finds strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
This is Teodora. She previously accessed an 15,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her family's daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Teodora dreams that her business will last longer and hopes to have a good life. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of God she studies.

All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Myraflor

texts.en:
Myraflor started with a frozen foods business. When she realized that her income was not enough to sustain their needs, Myraflor expanded her business with a retail store. She spent her profit from her business on the allowances of their children. There is still not enough to cover all her children's expenses but at least she anticipates an income to provide for some of her children's needs. 

Myraflor wants to borrow a loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to buy grocery items like beverages, biscuits, soap, shampoo and toothpaste to sell in their village. She hopes that someday her retail store will become a big grocery store.

loans.use: to buy grocery items like beverages, biscuits, soap, shampoo and toothpaste to sell in their village.

loans.name: Rechel

texts.en:
Rechel is separated from her husband and she has two children living with her. 

To make a living, she manages her farm, planting vegetables and root crops for sale. She needs to buy a new variety of seedlings and fertilizer for her new plot of garden, and without hesitation, she borrowed a loan from GDMPC, which she had joined in 2007. 

In the future, Rechel wants to improve the general living situation of her family.

loans.use: to buy a new variety of seedlings and fertilizer.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is 28 years old, married, and has one child. He is a youth client from Iraq and the only provider for his family. Ali owns a small shop where he sells mobile phone and accessories. He also provides his neighborhood with internet connections. He has been in this field since 2007 and has been gradually growing with experience. Ali now has an employee and is well-known in the surrounding area thanks to his provided services.

Ali is requesting for a youth loan for $2,400, which he will use to install a display window and a rolling shutter for his shop. Ali is aiming to expand his business and increase his profits so he may improve the quality of life of his family and provide them with better life standards.

loans.use: to install a display window and a rolling shutter for his shop

loans.name: Milton

texts.en:
Milton is 21 years old, married, and has one child. He lives in Kagadi, Uganda. He has a motorcycle transport business and also sells produce, which he has been doing for three years. He faces the challenge of price fluctuations.

Milton is requesting a loan, which he will use to buy more stock of beans and maize. He earns income to support his family and he serves the people of Kagadi and neighboring districts. His hopes to build his home and expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase beans and maize.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Nanuli

texts.en:
Nanuli is 51 years old and lives with her son, daughter-in-law and toddler grandson in the Batumi city. Nanuli is jobless at the moment and stays home. She owns a commercial space at the local shopping center and rents it out. Her son works as an electrician at the municipality and gets a small monthly salary. 

Nanuli requested a loan to start a beauty salon and hair care business in her city. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisions the provision of a business start-up and re-start-up credits with reasonable conditions for the country's vulnerable poor who do not have access to credit products since they are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of low income. 

Nanuli wants to purchase all the needed modern inventory for a haircare business. Her daughter-in-law will work as a hair stylist as she has proper experience in this field. According to Nanuli's estimates, the business will be lucrative and the increased profit will be reinvested in the same business. Nanuli will be able to increase the family's spending to satisfy their daily needs and improve theie standard of living.

loans.use: to start a beauty salon.

loans.name: Maria Elisa

texts.es:
Doña María Elisa tiene 56 años de edad es casada con un grado de educación de primaria completa ya que sus padres no tenían los recursos para poder ayudarle a culminar sus estudios a nivel secundario y universitario. Sin embargo le enseñaron a trabajar la tierra en lo que es el cultivo de café y granos básicos siendo madre de 7 hijos los cuales solo depende una hija que es adoptada la que tiene 16 años y está cursando el segundo curso del plan básico en el centro educativo de la comunidad. Bajo el mismo techo con ella también viven dos hijos que están con sus parejas sin embargo no dependen de ella. En familia cultivan maíz y frijoles solo para consumo de su hogar, sus cultivos están ubicados aproximadamente a 30 minutos caminando y 10 en vehículo. Llegada la corta se involucran todos los miembros de su familia y así se evitan el pago de mano de obra a personas particulares siendo sus clientes los diferentes intermediarios que llegan a la comunidad para comprar su producto.
La meta más importante que tiene es hacer crecer más su negocio y esto lo lograra dando un buen mantenimiento a sus cultivos y mediante la compra de más terreno. Por lo que hoy en día ella solicita financiamiento para la compra de insumos agrícolas como abono, foliares, fertilizantes entre otros con los que podrán asistir sus cultivos de café.
texts.en:
María Eliza is 56 years old, married, and educated through primary school, as her parents did not have the resources to be able to help her finish secondary or university-level education. However, they taught her to work the land where she grows coffee and other staples. She is mother to seven children, of whom only one is dependent: an adopted daughter, age 16, in her second year of the basic plan at the community education center.

Two of her other children live under her roof as well, both with their spouses, however, they are not dependent on her. As a family they grow corn and beans for themselves. These crops are located about a 30-minute walk or a 10-minute drive away. At harvest time, the whole family gets involved, so they don't have to hire any help. Their clients are various intermediaries who come to the community to buy their product.

Her most important goal is to continue growing her business, which she will accomplish by taking good care of her crop and buying more land. For this reason she is now requesting a loan to buy agricultural supplies such as compost, liquid fertilizer, fertilizers, and other products, with which to tend to her coffee crop.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies so she can tend to her coffee crop this season

loans.name: Kiponza Group

texts.en:
Ally, who is in his late 30's, is married and has four children, a girl and three boys. Ally's children are in school.

Since 2004, Ally has been running a business of fruits and vegetables. He is doing great in this project. He works from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a very good return per month. 

From Tujijenge Tanzania, this is Ally's third loan request, which he will use to buy fruits and vegetables to resell. With the previous loans, all of which he has paid back successfully, he restocked the out-of-stock items in his business. Ally uses his business profit to pay school fees and household expenses. He dreams of expanding his business by selling more fruits.

He will share this loan with his loan group,"Kiponza," which totals three members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married mother of one child who is still young. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

She has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 50,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Frida

texts.en:
Frida is a married mother of four children, all of whom go to school. They live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

For years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of lack of enough capital in her business and she dreams of establishing a big shop in the future. 

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar for sale in her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar.

loans.name: Hector

texts.es:
Hector es de la ciudad de Caaguazú, es una persona que está estudiando para ser un gran profesional y poder servir a la sociedad.
Está estudiando la carrera de odontología, y comenta que su sueño es poder tener su propio centro odontológico y ejercer exitosamente su profesión.
Cuenta también que es el menor de 4 hermanos, y que sus padres son divorciados.
Pide este préstamo para poder invertirlo en el pago de sus cuotas de la universidad, y también para poder pagar sus gastos de manutención y de transporte. También agradece por la oportunidad que está recibiendo de seguir estudiando.
texts.en:
Hector is from the city of Caaguazú and is currently studying to be a great professional so that he can serve society. He is studying to be a dentist and says that his dream is to have his own dentist's office to successfully practice his profession.  

He tells us that he is the youngest of four siblings and that his parents are divorced. He is requesting this loan to invest in the payment of his university fees, as well as to pay for accommodations and transportation. He is grateful for the opportunity that he is receiving to continue his studies.

loans.use: to pay university fees as well as accommodations and transportation costs.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is a 45-year-old married man with four children living in Kasese, Uganda. For six years he has been operating a retail shop and the business has been very lucrative.

He used the previous loan to buy general merchandise to sell. He also deals in the local brew, coffee and bananas for additional income. Like most traders he is challenged by price fluctuation and high cost of transport. His vision is to become a leading coffee exporter.

Godfrey intends to use the loan to buy coffee to sell.

loans.use: to buy coffee to sell.

loans.name: Mpipi Group

texts.en:
Seleman is in his early 40s, single, and has one child who attends school. He has been managing his family expenses by running a business selling charcoal. He also sells sand for building. He has been in these businesses for five years and is able to make a monthly profit. Seleman works from 7 AM to 7 PM. 

Seleman is requesting his 21st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which he will use to restock charcoal to sell. He used his previous loans to restock charcoal. He sold more sand and has used his profits to buy a plot of land and cover home expenses and school fees. 

Seleman will share this loan with the Mpipi Group, which consists of three members. The members of the group hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a married woman. She has six children, two of whom attend school while the others are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her two children.

She operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the challenge of stiff competition from other operators in her business.
 
With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase 6 sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 6 sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 35 years old and married, with three children.

She manages her own garden as an aid to her husband's income from employment as a driver. She has been raising vegetable for five years. 

Recently, she joined GDMPC, and she has borrowed a loan to buy fertilizer, such as manure. She is hopeful that through this loan, she would earn additional returns and be able to use her income for her children's future education.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, such as manure, for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintenance of the tricycles for her transportation business.

loans.name: Shaba Group

texts.en:
Naftal, who is in his early 30s, is married with two daughters who are in school. Since 2008, Naftal has had two businesses. One is a retail shop selling dry food items like rice, maize flour and other items. Naftal is also a photographer. He starts working from 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. per working day and is able to make a very good profit per month. 

This is his fourth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his previous loans to open a photo studio, where now he receives more jobs at parties and functions. He bought a big cameras and other related studio equipment to improve his service. 

Naftal has paid back all his loans successfully. With his business profit, he built a house and paid school fees and household expenses. He will use this loan to improve his retail shop by restocking more out-of-stock and missing products to resell. Naftal dreams to improve both of his businesses more.
 
He will share this loan with his loan group, Shaba, which totals six members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to improve his retail shop by restocking more out-of-stock and missing products to resell.

loans.name: Awa Sikina's Group

texts.fr: Ce groupe  est constitué de 6 femmes du même quartier qui s'activent dans le même domaine d'activité qui est le commerce. Madame Safietou âge de 58 ans qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est la représentante du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de sept enfants dont quatre garçons. Elle s'active dans la vente de légumes, de poissons, de la bouillie et du couscous. Activité qu'elle maitrise parfaitement car l'ayant pratiquée depuis plusieurs années. Les bénéfices serviront d'épargne, de subvenir aux besoins familiaux et d'aider son mari dans certains domaines d'activité.
texts.en: This group comprises six women from the same district who are active in the same business domain of commerce. Ms. Safietou, aged 58, is found at the right in the photo with her hand raised. She is the group's representative and a married mother of seven children, including four boys. She is active in selling vegetables, fish, porridge, and couscous. This is a business she has completely mastered for having been in operation for several years. The profits will go toward savings and to meet family needs, as well as to help out her husband with certain areas of work.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables, fish, and millet

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David, age 48, is from the small village of Oktomberi (October in English). He is married and has one toddler son. The family runs a small scale agricultural business and breeds two milk cows and two calves. David takes food to his livestock and his wife produces dairy products for selling and for family consumption as well. David works hard, but his earnings from the agricultural business are modest, especially now when grazing season in fields are finished and the family receives a small amount of milk from the cows. 

David is seeking a job but his attempts are unsuccessful as he doesn’t have education or any kind of profession. That is why he decided to purchase a car and start a taxi business. He has experience in driving and hopes his business will generate income. He wishes to provide his wife and child with better living conditions and give them what they need. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase a secondhand car and start a taxi business.

loans.name: Om-Wajdi Group

texts.en:
Om-Wajdi is a group of four poor women from Al-Hodeidah, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 90,000 YER to improve their businesses. Fawzia, a 31-year-old married woman, lives with her children in a small house in Al-Hodeidah city. She said that her husband is unable to cover all their household expenses. So she decided to work and earn money to cover the needs of her children. 

She is a door-to-door women's clothing saleswoman. She sells "dera'a", a traditional Yemeni dress. She has earned a good profit from this business, so she decided to purchase more clothes and target new clients. Therefore, she asked for a loan in the amount of 30,000 YER. She looks forward to opening a clothing store in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to attract more clients.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and fees.
 
She has operated a tailoring business for the past four years. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a big tailoring shop in the future. 

With the 50,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Rwad Group

texts.en:
The Rwad Group consists of four women from Al-Hodeida, Yemen. They asked for a loan of 100,000 YER [Yemen rials] to pay for purchasing woman's clothes, perfumes and incense. 

Araqia is 24 years old and a single woman. She lives with her family in the city of Al-Hodeida. Her family conditions are bad, so she has to help her family in paying for all living expenses. She is a door-to-door seller. She has been selling clothes for about a year. This business is making a good profit, so she decided to expand her business and start selling perfumes and incense. Therefore, she applied for a loan in the amount of 20,000 YER from AMB to buy clothes, perfumes and incense for resale to increase her profit.

loans.use: to buy clothes, perfumes and incense for resale to increase her profit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use:
to purchase equipment and tools to start her
natural water disbursement to local residents.

loans.name: Ariel

texts.en:
Ariel is thankful for the financial assistance extended to him. He was able to buy the spare parts and accessories that his tricycle needed. He has this business for two years now. He was able to help his family with the income that he generated from his business.

He would like to apply for another PHP 17,000 loan  to buy other spare parts and to maintain his Tricycle unit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Ariel hopes to have another unit of tricycle, and he dreams of having a lifetime partner. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay their microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintain his tricycle unit.

loans.name: Fidelite Group

texts.fr: La cliente  Mongani est une conseillère du collectif de crédit « Fidélité », doyenne, senior entrepreneur expérimentée, dynamique, âgée de 64 ans et mère de 8 enfants qui sont déjà mariés et ont tous leurs foyers. Son conjoint un chauffeur auprès d’une compagnie privée. La cliente est une vendeuse des boissons. Elle installe ses produits à son domicile. Elle commença ses affaires avec  l’assistance de son époux. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le prêt de l’IMF Hekima. Il ya 30 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité.  Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter 70 casiers de boissons (30 casiers de Primus, 20 casiers de Fanta, 10 casiers de Skol, 10 casiers de Mutzig). Ainsi, elle souhaite étendre son projet de commerce et passer le reste de sa vie en paix. La vente en crédit et les pertes de change sont de défis pour le développement de son activité. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour l’autonomisation des femmes entrepreneurs non bancables, surtout ; pendant ce moment critique de guerre à l’Est du pays.
texts.en: Mongani is the leader of the «Fidelité » savings group. She is a seasoned, experienced and energetic entrepreneur. She is 64 years old and has eight children, who are already married and have their own household. Her husband works as a driver for a private company. Mongani sells beverages. She sets up her wares by her home. She has launched her business with help from her husband. Later on, she obtained a loan from Hekima. She has been in this business for 30 years. This new loan will allow her to buy 70 cases of beverages (30 cases of Primus beer, 20 cases of Fanta, 10 cases of Skol beer, and 10 cases of Mutzig beer). Eventually she would like to fold her business and be able to enjoy her retirement. Her main challenges are selling on credit and currency exchange losses. Finally, she sincerely thanks Hekima for helping female entrepreneuers who do not have access to traditional banking become financially independent, especially at this critical moment while there is warfare in the east of the country.

loans.use: to buy 70 cases of various beverages.

loans.name: Mwanalima

texts.en:
Mwanalima is a married woman and has been blessed with four children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling household consumables like wheat flour, rice and cooking oil. She cites seasonality as her major challenge in the business. 

She is requesting 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to boost her kiosk, purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat

loans.name: Avtandil

texts.en:
Avtandil is 56 years old. He lives in the village of Kveda Sazano with his wife, two sons, daughter-in-law and a grandchild. Avtandil has chronic health problems and gets small-sized assistance from the government. 

In spite of his health problems, Avtandil works hard and is busy with agricultural activities. Specifically, he owns a vineyard and grows walnut trees in his plot of land. He works hard the whole year and harvests the quality products which are sold to retailers. Additionally, the family runs an animal husbandry business and breeds two pigs. 

The family lives below the poverty line, and according to government estimates, they belong to “vulnerable poor” category. 

With this loan, Avtandil would like to purchase a tractor. He will use it to perform agricultural work on the land of nearby farmers, mainly in the tilling and sowing seasons, and will be paid by the landlords. He will save any profits generated by the tractor and continue to cultivate his own land. His son will assist him in this business as well. He expects that this loan will significantly increase his family's income and enable him to provide better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to purchase a tractor to perform work on the land of nearby farmers.

loans.name: Leona

texts.en:
This is Leona. She previously accessed a 14,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures. For additional income, she also sells different groceries and toiletries.
 
She would like to apply for another 14,000 PHP loan to buy different beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and the children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Leona dreams of being more successful in her business and hopes to help her grandchildren with their schooling. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. This is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for different beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en: Elisa is running an entertainment business, offering music through VideoKey. She has been in this business for more than four years and she has earned well to help cover their needs. Recently, she joined GDMPC and taken out a loan to buy a new microphone for the VideoKey machine. As an aid to her husband's income, she has to find ways in order to entertain her customers. In the future, she wants to expand her business and become a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: to buy a new microphone for the VideoKey machine.

loans.name: Angelie

texts.en:
Angelie has run a general store for more than five years to earn a living. She is married, with one child. Aside from this, she also serves food in her cafeteria, and she earned an extra income for the family. 

Recently, she borrowed from GDMPC microcredit to buy more grocery goods for her store. She plans to used her revenue as additional capital to expand her business. 

In the future, Angelie wants to improve the general living of her entire family.

loans.use: to buy more grocery goods for her store

loans.name: Charo

texts.en:
Charo appreciates his previous Kiva loan, which improved his living standards and enabled him to earn a higher income from his motorcycle business.

He is now requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to purchase spare parts and paint his motorcycle.  He thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and paint his motorcycle

loans.name: Erhemmart

texts.en:
Erhemmart is 32 and lives with her husband and a daughter in a small house in the Bayanhoshuu area of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her husband runs a taxi service business in town and her daughter is a local school student. 

Erhemmart has been working as a saleswoman in a local market for years and started her business in a rental booth of the local market in 2005. She has been providing qualified organic fruits to local residents. She purchases from wholesalers and agriculturalists in large amounts from a bigger market. 

She is now requesting a loan of 5,000,000 MNT to purchase an eco-friendly, electric and fuel consuming hybrid car to reduce her transportation costs. She is a well-organized and hardworking woman.

loans.use: to purchase an eco-friendly, electric and fuel consuming hybrid car to reduce her transportation costs.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 49 years old and widowed, with four children. She runs a charcoal business in Tombo, a western rural area in Freetown. She started her business because she wanted to generate a permanent source of income.  

She's been in this business since the death of her husband during the rebel war and she sells charcoal at her house. She describes her major hardships as inadequate funds to run her business and transportation problems.  

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone Microfinance Company Limited to purchase more charcoal, to expand her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her level of living. 

In the future, she would like to change her business to a food stand store. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal, to expand her business.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
At the age of 31, Edward is still single. He finished college but was not given a chance for employment. However, he did not fail to find other sources of income in order to help his parents improve their life. Despite being unemployed, Edward earns income by running a bakery business in their village. He said that his type of business is laborious, but being patient and loving of the work is easy for him to manage. 

Edward wishes for a loan of PHP 40,000 to buy raw ingredients for baking breads. He has been almost five years in the business and hopes that it will last so he can still manage the business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for baking breads.

loans.name: Adolfo

texts.en: Adolfo is married with three children. He runs a service-based business providing motor transportation services. Adolfo carries passengers and baggage to different destinations to earn a living and as an aid to his income from farming. Adolfo joined GDMPC recently and borrowed a loan to buy motor accessories and tires. He wants to make sure of the good service he provides to his costumers. In the future, he wants to improve the general living situation of his family.

loans.use: to buy motor accessories and tires.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a widow and a mother of two children who attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water.

She sells fruits and green vegetables. She always struggles to improve her grocery stall, trying to sell more and save money to support her family. She is requesting a loan to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.use: to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Anelyn

texts.en:
This is Anelyn. She previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.
 
She would like to apply for another 35,000 PHP loan for her to buy more merchandise items and products to increase her product inventory. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. The profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Anelyn dreams to be more successful in business and hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise products, like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics, needed in her business.

loans.name: Sherly

texts.en:
Sherly is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more grocery items for her variety store, which she has run for five years now. Her loan also helped in the education of her child. Her income from business assisted in their everyday household expenditures. She and her partner are both working hard to provide for their family.

Sherly would like to apply for another loan, in the amount of PHP 10,000, to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell should result in greater profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her child’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Sherly hopes that her business will flourish and she dreams that her child will finish his studies. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business. There, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Wara

texts.en:
Meet 32-year-old Wara, from Tombo, a western, rural area in Freetown. She is married, with three children between the ages of five years and 15 years. Two of her children are going to school. 

After the war, Wara established her wax cotton business. She began her business because she needed to create income to support the home. She works at the business ten hours per day and seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is lack of enough capital to run her business.

Wara requires a loan in order to buy more wax cotton for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. 

In the future, Wara plans to own a big shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more wax cotton for resale.

loans.name: Pilika Pilika Group

texts.en:
Anselmina, who is in her late 50s, is single, with four children who have finished school. 

For three years now, she has been running a business, selling new clothes. Anselmina works from  6am to 4pm each working day and is able to make very good monthly returns.

This will be her first loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to buy clothes stock for her business. Anselmina, who is selling her clothes up-country, dreams to open a big clothes shop, so as to move away from door-to-door selling. 

Anselmina will share this loan with her loan  group, Pilika Pilika Group, which totals four members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes stock for her business.

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl is 32 years old and married, with five children.

Sheryl works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and she has requested a PHP 29,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Sheryl has borrowed and repaid twelve loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for seven years and she also earns an income from farming sugarcane and selling fruits and vegetables.

Sheryl aspires to save enough money, so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Flordelina

texts.en: Flordelina is married with four children. She runs a general store to add to her husband's income from employment. She also sells food and snacks in town. She borrowed a loan from GDMPC micro credit to buy additional grocery goods to sell. She plans to save money for the future needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
This is Riza. She previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children, and their personal household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and her children's education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Riza dreams to have another tricycle unit and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week.  This is also where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis.  A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners.  The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital and to pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintenance of her tricycle.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret appreciates her previous Kiva loan, which improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her cloth-selling business and earn a higher income.

She is now requesting a loan of KES 40,000 to purchase more bales of clothes for resale . She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Meet 27-year-old Fatmata from Tombo Western rural area in Freetown. She is married with 3 children aged 2 years and 12 years old. Two of her children are going to school. After the war, Fatmata established her fish business. She began her business because she needed to earn income to support her household. She works at the business 10 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is lack of enough capital to run it.

Fatmata requires a loan in order to buy more fish for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, Fatmata plans have a fishing boat for herself. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more fish for resale

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 42 years old, married, and has four children, three of whom attend school. She buys and sells recycled materials in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 10 years.

Elsie is requesting a loan from NWTF for 27,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase more stocks of scrap and recycled materials to sell. In the future, she would like to save money to buy a delivery truck for her business.

loans.use: to purchase scrap and recycled materials

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 53 years old and married with three children.

Rosemarie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Rosemarie has borrowed and repaid 21 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 32 years and also earns income from food vending.

Rosemarie aspires to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Chuchi

texts.en:
Chuchi is 60 years old and married with three children. Chuchi works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Chuchi has borrowed and repaid eleven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from soft-drink retail. Chuchi aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
This is Eufemia. She previously accessed an 25,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories, and for maintenance on their Jeepney unit. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household, and business expenditures.
 
She would like to apply for another 27,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and for maintenance on their Jeepney unit. Profits from her business will definitely help sustain her family's daily needs and her children's education. She looks forward to this additional income with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Eufemia hopes to buy another unit of Jeepney and dreams to give her children a good life and education. She meets with her co-fellowship members** every week to share stories of her work and to find strength and encouragement from the word of God, which she studies.

* Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater Jeepney. It is open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy enough for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the Jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly the Philippines.

** All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts, accessories, and maintenance on her Jeepney unit.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela's previous loan was a big help in her business and she is very thankful for it. Her loan helped her in her business and also in the education of her children. Her income from business assisted in meeting her family's everyday expenses at home. She is already a widow and that's why she works hard to provide for her family.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and farm inputs needed in her pineapple farming business. Her profits from his business will definitely help her sustain her family's daily needs and support her children's education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Marcela dreams that her farm will be expanded so she will have more fruits to plant and harvest. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fertilizer and farm inputs needed in her pineapple farming business

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
Benita previously requested a loan for 15,000 PHP, which she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her child’s education and in their personal, household, and business expenditures.
 
Benita is requesting another loan for 20,000 PHP, which she will use to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. profit. Her profits from business will help sustain her family’s daily needs and child’s education expenses. 

Benita hopes to be more successful in her business and to become rich. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and to draw strength and inspiration from God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items, toiletries, and beverages

loans.name: Haja

texts.en:
Haja is 28 years old, married, and has two children. She operates a fish business in Tombo, the western rural area in Sierra Leone. She faces the challenge of slow sales during the rainy season.

Haja is requesting a loan from BRAC Sierra Leone, which she will use to purchase more fish to sell. The extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family's welfare. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level.

loans.use: to purchase fish

loans.name: Claris

texts.en:
Claris is married and has no children. She owns a house that has neither piped water nor electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women. She cites seasonality as her major challenge and she dreams of establishing a boutique in the near future.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is a hard-working and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya.

Mbeyu has operated a clothes-selling business for the past two years. She sells door to door to her town to dwellers, passersby and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of inflation in her business. 

With the KES 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.ru: Илхомчону 20 лет. Он имеет средне -специальное образование. Илхомджон 3 месяца назад поступил на работу в микро финансовое учреждение. Он хочет усовершенствовать свои знания. Он хочет получить высшее образование. Он поступил в университет на первый курс. Илхомджон учится в факультете Финансы и кредит. Он не женат и живет с родителями. Он запрашивает займ для оплаты учебного договора. Он ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Ilhomjon is 20 years old.  He has a secondary-specialized education.  Three months ago, Ilhomjon started a new job at a micofinancing organization.  He wants to improve his knowledge by obtaining a university education.  He has enrolled into the first year of the university program at the department of Finance and Loans.  He is not married and lives with his parents.  He is asking for a loan to pay for his tuition costs.  He is waiting for your kindness.

loans.use: To pay for university education

loans.name: Nasanmonh

texts.en: Mrs. Nasanmonh is 35 years old, and lives with her 2 sons in a Ger, a traditional nomadic tent, in the Bayanhoshuu area of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her sons go to local schools. Nasanmonh moved to Ulaanbaatar city in 1999 from Bulgan province where her parents still live. Her sons go there in the summertime to help their grandparents herd livestock. Nasanmonh's husband passed away a few years ago and now she takes care of the family by herself. Nasanmonh started her business soon after she came to the city. Her sewing machine is broken and she needs to replace it to continue her business. She is now requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase a sewing machine to continue her tailoring business. She is a hardworking, diligent, and strong lady.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine to continue her tailoring business

loans.name: Arshaluys

texts.en: Arshaluys is from the Malishka village in the Vayots Dzor region. She lives with her husband. Both of them work hard to meet their needs. Arshaluys works in the village local self-governance body, and her husband works in the private sector. To cover their expenses, they are also engaged in breeding  livestock--cows and hens--and cultivating apricots, apples, pears and walnuts. In the present,it is very difficult for the family to fully cover their needs. This is why Arshaluys wants to increase their livestock a little bit. She needs a loan of USD 2100 to purchase two steers and forage for them. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back. However, thanks to hard work during the recent times, Arshaluys was able to organize her farming in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Arshaluys and her husband rely on the good will of the lenders and will be thankful to them for helping them sustain their lives.

loans.use: to purchase two steers and forage for them

loans.name: Parvona

texts.ru: Парвона молодая бизнес леди. Ей 23 года. Она замужем, но не имеет детей. Она более 3 лет занимается собственным бизнесом. Парвона в основном выращивает картошку и пшеницу. После того как она собирает урожай, она продаёт свой товар на местном рынке с первых рук по более низкой цене. Ее муж помогает ей по введению бизнеса. Парвона постепенно развивает бизнес и усовершенствует свои знания. Парвона хочет отремонтировать свой дом, так как она живет в плохом жилищном условии.
